sub_topic: Prove that the power set of a set is always larger than the set itself.
message_1: Let X be a set containing exactly 4 elements. Calculate the number of elements in the power set of X, and show that the power set of X is always strictly larger than X.
message_2:
Let X be a set containing exactly 4 elements, i.e., X = {a, b, c, d}. The power set of X, denoted as P(X), is the set of all possible subsets of X, including the empty set and X itself.

To calculate the number of elements in the power set of X, we can use the formula:

|P(X)| = 2^|X|

where |P(X)| represents the number of elements in the power set of X, and |X| represents the number of elements in X.

In this case, |X| = 4, so:

|P(X)| = 2^4 = 16

Thus, the power set of X contains 16 elements.

Now, let's show that the power set of X is always strictly larger than X. We know that |X| = 4 and |P(X)| = 16. Since 16 > 4, it is clear that the power set of X is strictly larger than X. In general, for any set Y with |Y| = n, the power set of Y will have 2^n elements, which will always be strictly larger than n.
